title: 112_s922
content: The Urban Jobs Act of 2011 may be cited as the ``Urban Jobs Act of 2011''. Congress finds that one-third of minority youth are unemployed, the labor force participation rate is lower for individuals without a high school diploma, African-American and Hispanic students have a lower graduation rate, high school dropouts cost the nation billions in lost wages, and only 52 percent of students in large cities graduate from high school. The national high school graduation rate is 70 percent, falling short of the 60 percent average for urban districts. High school dropouts earn significantly less over a lifetime and are more likely to end up in prison. Increasing the high school completion rate has the potential to save billions annually and reduce crime rates. The Act aims to reduce crime rates by providing resources to national nonprofit organizations to prevent disproportionate incarceration of eligible youth, especially minority youth. It offers services like job training, education, and support to prepare youth for economic self-sufficiency and advancement. SEC. 3. URBAN JOBS PROGRAMS. Amends the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to include a new section on Urban Jobs Programs. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for youth aged 18-24 in urban communities, offering services to prepare them for employment or education leading to employment, and reducing disproportionate youth incarceration. The section aims to provide competitive grants for establishing a feeder system for eligible youth aged 18-24 in urban communities, including minority youth, who are not enrolled in school or have been involved in the criminal justice process. Eligible youth are defined as individuals who meet specific criteria and are targeted for services to reduce disproportionate incarceration rates. The Urban Jobs Program aims to provide grants for outreach and workforce activities to eligible youth in urban communities. Recidivism is defined as a tendency to return to criminal behavior, and an unsubsidized job is one that pays wages without public funds. Urban Jobs Program Grants are for programs funded under subsection (c). The Urban Jobs Program Grants authorize the Secretary to provide grants to national intermediaries for Urban Jobs Programs in urban communities, offering services to youth for employment or education leading to employment. To be eligible for a grant, intermediaries must submit an application with specified requirements. The national intermediary must submit a grant request specifying the amount and proposed uses of funds, along with a description of how they will achieve goals for Urban Jobs Program participants. These goals include increased long-term employment, reduced recidivism, improved education attainment, literacy, and numeracy. The curr_chunk describes the underlying supports for the program, including engaged community partners, staff expertise in youth development, and demonstrated understanding of youth characteristics. It also outlines how the program will enable participants to achieve outcomes such as industry-recognized certificates or credentials and preparation for higher education without remediation. The curr_chunk outlines outcomes including creating caring relationships with peers and staff, setting goals like employment or higher education attainment, and participating in opportunities to contribute. The curr_chunk highlights the benefits of community service, developing 21st-century workplace skills, fostering a sense of responsibility, creating plans to achieve goals, reducing risk-taking behaviors, and improving educational outcomes. The curr_chunk describes the activities and services provided through the Urban Jobs Program to achieve industry-recognized certificates and credentials. The Urban Jobs Program offers case management, educational services, and employment/job readiness activities to help participants navigate the program, improve skills, and prepare for career pathways or higher education. The Urban Jobs Program provides employment and job readiness activities such as mentoring, internships, and occupational skills training. It also offers support services like health referrals, substance abuse counseling, and housing assistance. Only 2 percent of funds can be used for expenses related to these services. The Urban Jobs Program provides employment and job readiness activities through national intermediaries. The program is not subject to evaluations required under section 172. The Secretary of Labor will establish the National Jobs Council Advisory Committee. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee, referred to as the Committee, consists of 11 members appointed by the Secretary. Members include individuals from the private sector with HR or diversity experience, representatives from high-impact industries, a national intermediary staff member, and representatives from the Department of Labor. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee consists of 11 members appointed for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Committee analyzes program design, strategic priorities, and guidelines, preparing recommendations for the Secretary. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee consists of 11 members appointed for life. They prepare periodic reports with recommendations for the Secretary. Committee members do not receive compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee may accept voluntary services from members without compensation. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Committee without reimbursement. The Committee is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Congress suggests that community-based affiliates establish local advisory committees to support and guide program implementation. The National Jobs Council Advisory Committee can accept voluntary services from members without compensation. Funding for Urban Jobs Programs is authorized to be appropriated for fiscal years 2012-2016. Amendments are made to the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to support program implementation. Amendments are made to the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 to support program implementation by inserting a period at the end of the item relating to section 173A and inserting a new item after it. Amendments to the Workforce Investment Act of 1998 include the addition of a new section, "Sec. 173B. Urban jobs programs."
